label: Trial of Jesus before Pontius Pilate

accounts.summary: Jesus is brought to Pilate, questioned about being king of the Jews, largely silent, and ultimately handed over to be crucified after the crowd chooses Barabbas.
accounts.notes: Portrays Pilate as surprised at Jesus' silence yet willing to satisfy the crowd.

accounts.summary: Pilate questions Jesus, receives a warning dream through his wife, offers to release Barabbas or Jesus, and symbolically washes his hands before ordering crucifixion.
accounts.notes: Emphasizes Pilate's reluctance and transfer of responsibility to the crowd who accept bloodguilt.

accounts.summary: Pilate examines the charges, sends Jesus to Herod, and three times declares he finds no basis for death, yet finally grants the crowd's demand to crucify Jesus.
accounts.notes: Highlights repeated declarations of innocence and political dynamics of the trial.

accounts.summary: Pilate interrogates Jesus about kingship and truth, has him flogged, and repeatedly tries to release him but yields under pressure when the leaders invoke Caesar.
accounts.notes: Presents an extended dialogue exploring Jesus' kingdom and Pilate's fear of political repercussions.
